elements.content: Reactions of 2-(1-imidazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1‘-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (ImhedpH4) and cobalt or nickel salts under hydrothermal conditions lead to four new metal phosphonates with two types of structures:  M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H2O [M = Co(II) (1) and Ni(II) (2)] and M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co(II) (3) and Ni(II) (4)]. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and show a layered structure made up of M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4 trimer units. These trimers are connected by edge-sharing of the {Co(2)O6} octahedra, forming an undulating chain. The adjacent chains are fused through the coordination of the phosphonate oxygen atom from one chain to the Co(2) atom of the other, thus generating a two-dimensional layer containing 4-, 8-, and 16-membered rings. The imidazole groups are grafted on the two sides of the layer. Compounds 3 and 4 are also isostructural and show a mononuclear structure with extensive hydrogen bond interactions. Magnetic measurements reveal that both 1 and 2 exhibit canted antiferromagnetism at 2.6 and 5.0 K, respectively. Below these temperatures, slow relaxation is observed from the ac susceptibility measurements corresponding to the spin-glass-like behaviors.

Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and show a layered structure made up of M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4 trimer units. These trimers are connected by edge-sharing of the {Co(2)O6} octahedra, forming an undulating chain. The adjacent chains are fused through the coordination of the phosphonate oxygen atom from one chain to the Co(2) atom of the other, thus generating a two-dimensional layer containing 4-, 8-, and 16-membered rings. The imidazole groups are grafted on the two sides of the layer. Compounds 3 and 4 are also isostructural and show a mononuclear structure with extensive hydrogen bond interactions. Magnetic measurements reveal that both 1 and 2 exhibit canted antiferromagnetism at 2.6 and 5.0 K, respectively. Below these temperatures, slow relaxation is observed from the ac susceptibility measurements corresponding to the spin-glass-like behaviors.

elements.content: Compounds M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H20 [M = Co(II) (1) and Ni(II) (2)] with a layer structure and M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co(II) (3) and Ni(II) (4)] with a mononuclear structure have been reported, where ImhedpH4 represents 2-(1-imidazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1‘-ethylidenediphosphonic acid. Both 1 and 2 exhibit canted ferromagnetism at ca. 2.6 and 5.0 K, respectively, below which slow relaxation is observed corresponding to the spin-glass-like behaviors.

elements.content: Layered metal phosphonates are considered a very large and versatile class of layered materials in which many different geometrical arrangements can be realized by an appropriate choice of the layered structure and/or the organic group. In some cases, a slight modification of the ligand and/or the reaction condition is sufficient to alter the structure and hence the magnetic properties. For example, a few cobalt diphosphonates with layered structures have been reported based on methylenediphosphonate and its derivatives (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Layered metal phosphonates are considered a very large and versatile class of layered materials in which many different geometrical arrangements can be realized by an appropriate choice of the layered structure and/or the organic group. In some cases, a slight modification of the ligand and/or the reaction condition is sufficient to alter the structure and hence the magnetic properties. For example, a few cobalt diphosphonates with layered structures have been reported based on methylenediphosphonate and its derivatives (Scheme ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic701098th00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="ic-2007-01098t_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The reaction of cobalt salt with methylenediphosphonic acid (mdpH4) result in a layered compound Na2Co(O3PCH2PO3)·H2O where the CoO5 square pyramids are corner-shared with the CPO3 tetrahedra forming a layer containing 12-membered rings. The use of aminomethylenediphosphonic acid (amdpH4) affords NaCo2{NH3CH(PO3)(PO3H0.5)}2(H2O)2·xH2O in which the CoO6 octahedra and CPO3 tetrahedra are connected through vertex-sharing, forming a layer containing 8- and 16-membered rings. When 1-aminoethylidenediphosphonic acid (aedpH4) is used, compound Co3{CH3C(NH3)(PO3H)(PO3)}2{CH3C(NH3)(PO3H)2}2(H2O)4·2H2O is obtained where corner-sharing CoO6 octahedra and CPO3 tetrahedra lead to a two-dimensional layer containing 24-membered rings. The use of 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate (hedpH4) produces Na6Co7(hedp)2(hedpH)4(H2O)4·8H2O, which bears a layered structure composing of two types of chains:  {Co3(hedp)2} n (chain I) made up of the CoO6 octahedra and CPO3 tetrahedra through corner-sharing and {Co2(hedpH)2} n (chain II) containing edge-shared CoO6 octahedra bridged by hedpH3- groups. The magnetic properties of the former three compounds are simply paramagnetic with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the magnetic center, while the latter compound experiences a two-step magnetic phase transition in the field range 0−70 kOe, corresponding to a metamagnetic transition from an antiferromagnetic state to a ferrimagnetic state followed by the transition from a ferrimagnetic state to a ferromagnetic state.

The magnetic properties of the former three compounds are simply paramagnetic with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the  magnetic center, while the latter compound experiences a two-step magnetic phase transition in the field range 0-70 kOe, corresponding to a metamagnetic transition from an antiferromagnetic state to a ferrimagnetic state followed by the transition from a ferrimagnetic state to a ferromagnetic state.

elements.content: To explore new metal diphosphonate materials with novel types of layer structures, we employ the 2-(1-imidazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1‘-ethylidenediphosphonic acid [ImhedpH4, (1-C3H3N2)CH2C(OH)(PO3H2)2] (Scheme ) where the imidazole group is introduced to hedpH4. ImhedpH4 is also called zoledronic acid and has been widely investigated as a third-generation bisphosphonate drug for treating diseases associated with increased bone resorption. As far as we are aware, no metal−Imhedp compound has been reported in the literature except Na+·C5H9N2O7P2 -·4H2O. In this paper, we report four compounds based on zoledronic acid with formula M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H2O [M = Co(1), Ni (2)], and M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co (3), Ni (4)]. Both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit a new type of layer structure and show weak ferromagnetism and spin-glass-like behaviors at low temperature.

ImhedpH4 is also called zoledronic acid and has been widely investigated as a third-generation bisphosphonate drug for treating diseases associated with increased bone resorption. As far as we are aware, no metal-Imhedp compound has been reported in the literature except Na+⋅C5H9N2O7P2 -⋅4H2O. In this paper, we report four compounds based on zoledronic acid with formula M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4⋅2H2O [M = Co(1), Ni (2)], and M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co (3), Ni (4)]. Both compounds 1 and 2 exhibit a new type of layer structure and show weak ferromagnetism and spin-glass-like behaviors at low temperature.

Materials and Methods . 2-(1-imidazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1‘-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (ImhedpH4) was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were purchased as reagent-grade chemicals and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr disks on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on microcrystalline samples (9.87 mg for 1 and 18.49 mg for 2), using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made for both the sample holder and the compound estimated from Pascal's constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods . 2-(1-imidazole)-1-hydroxyl-1,1‘-ethylidenediphosphonic acid (ImhedpH4) was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were purchased as reagent-grade chemicals and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr disks on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on microcrystalline samples (9.87 mg for 1 and 18.49 mg for 2), using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made for both the sample holder and the compound estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Preparation of Co 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (1). A mixture of ImhedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0272 g) and Co(CH3CO2)2·4H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.0249 g) in 8 mL of H2O, adjusted to pH = 4.49 with 1 M NaOH, was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 160 °C for 48 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple blocky crystals were collected as a monophasic material based on the powder XRD. Yield:  23 mg (56% based on Co). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C10H26N4O20P4Co3:  C, 14.42 (14.59); H, 3.06 (3.18); N, 6.68 (6.81). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3426(m, br), 3147(m), 2993(m), 1662(w, br), 1573(m), 1545(w), 1455(w), 1386(w), 1319(vw), 1288(m), 1225(vw), 1150(vs), 1051(vs), 979(s), 951(m), 926(m), 894(m), 851(m), 756(w), 711(w), 682(w), 638(m), 604(vw), 577(m), 545(m), 512(w), 481(m), 434(w).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallographic Studies. Single crystals of dimensions 0.2 × 0.15 × 0.1 mm for 1, 0.07 × 0.05 × 0.03 mm for 2, 0.06 × 0.05 × 0.04 mm for 3, and 0.08 × 0.06 × 0.05 mm for 4 were used for structural determinations on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer (for 1, 3, and 4) or a Bruker SMART 1K CCD diffractometer (for 2) using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. A hemisphere of data was collected in the θ range of 2.17−26.00° for 1, 2.19−26.00° for 2, 2.39−25.00° for 3, and 2.61−25.00° for 4 using a narrow-frame method with scan widths of 0.30° in ω and an exposure time of 5 s/frame. The numbers of observed and unique reflections are 3282 and 2331 (R int = 0.0213) for 1, 4335 and 2382 (R int = 0.0274) for 2, 2620 and 1826 (R int = 0.0227) for 3, and 2626 and 1801 (R int = 0.0243) for 4. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full matrix least squares using SHELXTL. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically, with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-H atom to which they are bonded. The crystallographic data for the four compounds are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables −5. CCDC publication nos. 645353−645356 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

Syntheses. Compounds 1−4 were prepared through hydrothermal reactions of ImhedpH4 and the corresponding metal acetates or sulfates at 160 or 140 °C for 2 days. It was found that the reaction temperature and pH value of the reaction mixture, M/ligand molar ratio, and the metal source play key roles in the formation of the final products. Both 1 and 2 can be prepared as pure phases at 160 °C, pH of 4.5−5.0, and with the M(CH3CO2)2/ligand molar ratio of (0.8−1):1. When the temperature is lowered to 140 °C or the pH value is beyond the range of 4.5−5.0, only flocculelike materials are obtained. Pure phases of compounds 3 and 4 can be obtained at 140 °C when the pH falls in the range of 2.5−3.0 and the MSO4/ligand molar ratio is (0.5−1):1. If we use MSO4 as the starting material in preparing 1 and 2 or M(CH3CO2)2 in preparing 3 and 4, large amounts of the unrecognized flocculelike materials would be obtained. Attempts to synthesize compounds 1 and 2 by using 3 and 4, respectively, as the starting materials were not successful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. Compounds 1-4 were prepared through hydrothermal reactions of ImhedpH4 and the corresponding metal acetates or sulfates at 160 or 140 °C for 2 days. It was found that the reaction temperature and pH value of the reaction mixture, M/ligand molar ratio, and the metal source play key roles in the formation of the final products. Both 1 and 2 can be prepared as pure phases at 160 °C, pH of 4.5-5.0, and with the M(CH3CO2)2/ligand molar ratio of (0.8-1):1. When the temperature is lowered to 140 °C or the pH value is beyond the range of 4.5-5.0, only flocculelike materials are obtained. Pure phases of compounds 3 and 4 can be obtained at 140 °C when the pH falls in the range of 2.5-3.0 and the MSO4/ligand molar ratio is (0.5-1):1. If we use MSO4 as the starting material in preparing 1 and 2 or M(CH3CO2)2 in preparing 3 and 4, large amounts of the unrecognized flocculelike materials would be obtained. Attempts to synthesize compounds 1 and 2 by using 3 and 4, respectively, as the starting materials were not successful.

elements.content: Crystal Structures of M 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O [M = Co(II) (1), Ni(II) (2)]. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, crystallizing in triclinic space group P1̄. Figure displays the building unit of 1. It contains two independent Co atoms with the Co1 atom sitting in an inversion center and Co2 at a general position. Both have a distorted-octahedral geometry. Four equatorial sites around the Co1 atom are occupied by phosphonate oxygens (O1, O4, O1A, and O4A) from two equivalent ImhedpH- ligands. The remaining two axial sites are filled with two equivalent water molecules (O1W and O1WA). For the Co2 atom, three of its six coordination sites are occupied by O2, O5, and O7 from the same ImhedpH- ligand, while the other three positions are filled with two phosphonate oxygens (O2C and O6B) from the other two equivalent ImhedpH- ligands and one water molecule (O2W). The Co−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.001(3)−2.180(3) Å, in agreement with those in (NH4)2Co2(hedpH)2, [NH3(CH2) n NH3]Co2(hedpH)2·2H2O, and [NH3C6H4NH3]Co2(hedpH)2·H2O.

elements.content: The ImhedpH- molecule serves as a hexadentate ligand. It chelates and bridges Co1 and Co2 by using four phosphonate oxygens (O1, O2, O4, O5) and the hydroxyl oxygen O7, hence forming a trimer unit of Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4. These trimers are connected by edge-sharing of the {Co(2)O6} octahedra, forming an undulating chain along the c axis, which contains a {Co2O2} dimer unit. The Co2−O2−Co2C angle within this dimer is 92.75(12)°. The Co2···Co2C distance is 3.023 Å. The adjacent chains are fused through the coordination of the phosphonate oxygen atom (O6) from one chain to the Co(2) atom from the other, hence generating a two-dimensional layer containing 4-, 8-, and 16-membered rings (Figure ). The remaining one phosphonate oxygen (O3) is protonated. The Co···Co distances across the O−P−O units are 5.372, 4.561, 4.859, and 6.336 Å for Co2···Co1, Co2···Co2B, Co2···Co1D, and Co2···Co1E, respectively.

elements.content: The structure of compound 2 is analogous to that of 1 except that the Co(II) ion in 1 is replaced by Ni(II) in 2. The Ni−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.006(4)−2.121(4) Å, comparable to those in the other nickel phosphonate compounds such as (enH2)Ni(hedpH2)2·2H2O. Within the layer, the Ni···Ni distance across the μ-O bridge is 3.001 Å, and those across the O−P−O units are 5.319 Å for Ni2· ··Ni1, 4.538 Å for Ni2···Ni2B, 4.822 Å for Ni2···Ni1D, and 6.312 Å for Ni2···Ni1E, which are distances slightly shorter than the corresponding Co···Co distances in compound 1 due to the smaller ionic radii of the Ni(II) ion. The Ni2−O2−Ni2C bond angle is 94.02(17)°, larger than that in 1. Extensive hydrogen bonds are also observed in 2. The interlayer separation is about 9.625(3) Å. To the best of our knowledge, this type of layered structure has not been observed in the other metal diphosphonate compounds.

elements.content: Crystal Structures of M(ImhedpH 3 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 [M = Co(II) (3), Ni(II) (4)]. Compounds 3 and 4 are isostructural. Each exhibits a mononuclear structure consisting of one M(II), two ImhedpH3 - ligands, and two coordination water molecules. Figure shows the molecular structure of 3 with its atomic labeling scheme. The Co1 atom lies in an inversion center and has a slightly distorted-octahedral geometry. Two pairs of phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O4, O1A, O4A) from two equivalent ImhedpH3 - ligands define the equatorial plane, while two equivalent water molecules (O1W and O1WA) occupy the axial sites. The Co1−O bond lengths are 2.050(4)−2.123(5) Å. The O−Co1−O bond angles are 84.77(17)−95.23(17)°. Each ImhedpH3 - acts as a bidentate ligand and chelates to the Co1 atom by using phosphonate oxygen atoms O1 and O4. Two of the remaining four phosphonate oxygens are protonated [P1−O3 = 1.568(4) Å and P2−O6 = 1.571(4) Å]. An extensive hydrogen-bonding network is found among the phosphonate oxygens, hydroxyl groups, the protonated imidazole group, and water molecules, hence forming a three-dimensional supramolecular structure (Figure ). The shortest O(N)···O distances are 2.592(6) Å for O3···O2ii, 2.663(6) Å for O6···O5iii, 2.871(6) Å for O7···O5iii, and 2.713(7) Å for N2···O4iv (symmetry code:  ii, −x + 1, −y + 1, −z; iii, −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1; iv, −x + 1, −y, −z + 1). Structure 4 is analogous to that of 3 except that the Co atoms are replaced by the Ni atoms.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties of Co 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (1). The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of compound 1 were investigated in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Co3 unit (8.78 μB) is much higher than the expected spin-only value for S = 3/2 (6.71 μB), attributed to the orbital contribution of Co(II) ion. The susceptibility data between 90 and 300 K follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = −12.3 K. Upon cooling from room temperature, χM T decreases continuously until it reaches a minimum of 6.78 cm3·K·mol-1 at 10 K. Below 10 K, χM T increases abruptly to a maximum of 14.82 cm3·K·mol-1 at 3 K and then decreases again to 9.46 cm3·K·mol-1 at 1.8 K (Figure ). This is characteristic for a ferrimagnetic behavior with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. Besides, the zero-field-cooled magnetism (ZFCM) and field-cooled magnetism (FCM, H dc = 50 Oe) measurements of the dc magnetic susceptibility deviate from each other at ca. 2.6 K, suggesting the onset of a long-range ferromagnetic phase transition below this temperature (Figure , inset).

elements.content: The ferromagnetic transition is confirmed by the field-dependent isothermal magnetization M(H) performed at 1.8 K. As shown in Figure , an abrupt increase of magnetization to a value of ca. 0.57 Nβ is observed at 0.4 kOe. Between 0.4 and ca. 10 kOe, the magnetization shows a linear increase. When the external field is further increased, the magnetization experiences an S-shaped increase and approaches a value of 2.12 Nβ at 70 kOe (Figure ). No magnetic hysteresis is present even at 1.8 K which classifies this material as a soft weak ferromagnet.

elements.content: According to the structure of compound 1, the Co(II) ions within the layer are bridged by μ-O and O−P−O units. Although the intralayer interactions through these exchange pathways are principally antiferromagnetic, the odd number of the Co(II) ions in the trimer unit of Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4 leads to a nonzero net magnetic moment. This corresponds to an intralayer ferromagnetic-like behavior as observed in 1. For the Co(II) ion in an octahedral environment, an effective spin of 1/2 with anisotropic g is usually expected at low temperature due to the overall effect of crystal-field and spin−orbit coupling. Therefore, the ferromagnetic-like layer of {Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4} n would result in one uncompensated S = 1/2 spin, and a magnetization value of 2.1−2.5 Nβ would be anticipated with g = 4.1−5.0.

This corresponds to an intralayer ferromagnetic-like behavior as observed in 1. For the Co(II) ion in an octahedral environment, an effective spin of 1/2 with anisotropic g is usually expected at low temperature due to the overall effect of crystal-field and spin-orbit coupling. Therefore, the ferromagnetic-like layer of {Co3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4} n  would result in one uncompensated S = 1/2 spin, and a magnetization value of 2.1-2.5 Nβ would be anticipated with g = 4.1-5.0.

elements.content: Since the saturation value of magnetization at 0.4 kOe (0.57 Nβ per Co3) is well below the expected value (M S = 2.1−2.5 Nβ), the observed ferromagnetic-like ordering is attributed to canted antiferromagnetism (weak ferromagnetism) between the layers; i.e., perfect antiparallel alignment of the spins on neighboring metal ions between the antiferromagnetically coupled layers is not achieved, so residual spins are generated. The canting angle α is estimated to be 1.1° calculated from the expression sin(α) = M R/M S, where M R of 0.041 Nβ is deduced from the extrapolation of the linear portion of higher magnetic field and M S of 2.1 Nβ is used. The magnetization value at 70 kOe (2.12 Nβ per Co3) is close to the expected value of 2.1−2.5 Nβ, indicating a metamagnetic transition from a weak ferromagnetic state to a ferrimagnetic state. The critical field of this metamagnetic transition is ca. 38 kOe.
elements.clean_text: Since the saturation value of magnetization at 0.4 kOe (0.57 Nβ per Co3) is well below the expected value (M S = 2.1-2.5 Nβ), the observed ferromagnetic-like ordering is attributed to canted antiferromagnetism (weak ferromagnetism) between the layers; i.e., perfect antiparallel alignment of the spins on neighboring metal ions between the antiferromagnetically coupled layers is not achieved, so residual spins are generated. The canting angle α is estimated to be 1.1° calculated from the expression sin(α) = M R/M S, where M R of 0.041 Nβ is deduced from the extrapolation of the linear portion of higher magnetic field and M S of 2.1 Nβ is used. The magnetization value at 70 kOe (2.12 Nβ per Co3) is close to the expected value of 2.1-2.5 Nβ, indicating a metamagnetic transition from a weak ferromagnetic state to a ferrimagnetic state. The critical field of this metamagnetic transition is ca. 38 kOe.

elements.content: To obtain the critical temperature of the long-range magnetic ordering precisely, the zero-field ac magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed under H ac = 5 Oe and a frequency of 1−499 Hz. Surprisingly, both the in-phase and out-of-phase signals, χM‘ and χM‘ ‘, display a maximum which is strongly frequency dependent (Figure ), implying a slow relaxation process. This slow relaxation process could be caused by either domain wall movements or spin-glass behaviors. The shift of the peak temperature (T p) of χM‘ is measured by a parameter φ = (ΔT p/T p)/Δ(log f) = 0.03 (f is the frequency of H ac), which is in the range of a normal spin-glass. The frequency dependence of T p on χM‘ ‘ can be fitted well to the Arrhenius law:  τ(T) = τ0 exp(Δ/k B T), where τ0 is the pre-exponential factor and Δ is the energy gap. The best fit results in parameters τ0 = 1.2 × 10-10 s and Δ/k B = 46 K. The activation energy may be compared with those typical for the domain wall movements.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties of Ni 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (2). The magnetic behavior of compound 2 is analogous to that of compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Ni3 unit (5.60 μB) is close to the expected value (5.38 μB) for spin S = 1 with g = 2.2. Upon cooling from room temperature, the χM T value decreases from 3.92 to 3.17 cm3·K·mol-1 at ca. 14 K, below which it increases rapidly to a maximum of 15.78 cm3·K·mol-1 at 5 K and then decreases again to 7.40 cm3·K·mol-1 at 1.8 K (Figure ). This is typical for ferrimagnetic behavior. The FCM (H dc = 50 Oe) and ZFCM curves diverge at ca. 5.0 K (Figure , inset), suggesting that a long-range magnetic ordering occurs below T c = 5.0 K. The isothermal magnetization M(H) at 1.8 K reveals that the magnetization at 70 kOe (0.86 Nβ) is far below the saturation value of 2.2 Nβ expected for an S = 1 system (g = 2.2), indicating the occurrence of canted antiferromagnetism. The magnetic hysteresis loop is observed at 1.8 K with the coercive field (H c) and the remnant magnetization (M R) being 22.5 Oe and 0.098 Nβ, respectively (Figure ). The canting angle is estimated as 2.6°.

elements.content: Canted antiferromagnetism, caused by an antisymmetrical component of the superexchange interaction (Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya interaction) and also by single ion anisotropy, has already been found in a few other cobalt or nickel phosphonate compounds including {K2[CoO3PCH2N(CH2CO2)2]}6· xH2O, Co3(O3PC2H4CO2)2, and Ni{CH3(CH2)17PO3}(H2O). The observation of canted antiferromagnetism in 1 and 2 is not unexpected due to the unsymmetrical exchange couplings between the neighboring metal ions. However, the coexistence of the slow relaxation process in a layered cobalt or nickel phosphonate compound is unusual. This relaxation process could be due to the spin-glass behaviors and/or domain wall movements. The small φ values obtained from the frequency dependence of T p on χM‘ support a spin-glass behavior in both 1 and 2, while the activation energies obtained from the frequency dependence of T p on χM‘ ‘ suggest the presence of domain wall movements. Apparently, compounds 1 and 2 show quite unusual magnetic behaviors and are tentatively ascribed to the canted antiferromagnet with spin-glass-like relaxation. Since the randomness (defects, disorder, etc.) and frustration (geometrical or competitive) are responsible for the spin-glass system, the spin-glass-like behavior of compounds 1 and 2 could be related to the possible crystal defects and/or the presence of some degree of frustration caused by the triangle arrangement of the cobalt(II) ions linked by three phosphonate oxygen atoms (Co1, Co2, and Co2B, for instance) in the magnetic lattice. Weak ferromagnetism with slow relaxation behavior has already been observed in a few coordination polymers including [Ni(μ-N3)(bmdt)(N3)](DMF) [bmdt = N,N‘-bis(4-methoxylbenzyl)-diethylenetriamine and DMF = dimethylformamide] and [Co3(DMF)12][W(CN)8]2 with chain structures, [Ni(C6H14N2)2]3[Fe(CN)6]2·2H2O with a layer structure, and [Co4(2-mna)4(OH2)] (2-mna = 2-mercaptonicotinate) with a three-dimensional structure.

elements.content: By the use of zoledronic acid, compounds M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4·2H2O [M = Co(II) (1) and Ni(II) (2)] with a novel type of layer structure and compounds M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co(II) (3) and Ni(II) (4)] with a mononuclear structure have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Both 1 and 2 show canted antiferromagnetism at 2.6 and 5.0 K, respectively, below which spin-glass-like relaxation behavior is observed. As far as we know, these are the first examples of metal phosphonates that exhibit the coexistence of weak ferromagnetism and relaxation behaviors. Further work is in progress to explore materials with new topologies and interesting magnetic properties based on the related diphosphonate ligands involving different functional groups.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By the use of zoledronic acid, compounds M3(ImhedpH)2(H2O)4⋅2H2O [M = Co(II) (1) and Ni(II) (2)] with a novel type of layer structure and compounds M(ImhedpH3)2(H2O)2 [M = Co(II) (3) and Ni(II) (4)] with a mononuclear structure have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. Both 1 and 2 show canted antiferromagnetism at 2.6 and 5.0 K, respectively, below which spin-glass-like relaxation behavior is observed. As far as we know, these are the first examples of metal phosphonates that exhibit the coexistence of weak ferromagnetism and relaxation behaviors. Further work is in progress to explore materials with new topologies and interesting magnetic properties based on the related diphosphonate ligands involving different functional groups.

Preparation of Co 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (1). A mixture of ImhedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0272 g) and Co(CH3CO2)2·4H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.0249 g) in 8 mL of H2O, adjusted to pH = 4.49 with 1 M NaOH, was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 160 °C for 48 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple blocky crystals were collected as a monophasic material based on the powder XRD. Yield:  23 mg (56% based on Co). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C10H26N4O20P4Co3:  C, 14.42 (14.59); H, 3.06 (3.18); N, 6.68 (6.81). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3426(m, br), 3147(m), 2993(m), 1662(w, br), 1573(m), 1545(w), 1455(w), 1386(w), 1319(vw), 1288(m), 1225(vw), 1150(vs), 1051(vs), 979(s), 951(m), 926(m), 894(m), 851(m), 756(w), 711(w), 682(w), 638(m), 604(vw), 577(m), 545(m), 512(w), 481(m), 434(w).

Preparation of Ni 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (2). A mixture of ImhedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0272 g) and Ni(CH3CO2)2·4H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.0249 g) in 8 mL of H2O, adjusted to pH = 4.50 with 1 M NaOH, was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 160 °C for 48 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, green blocky crystals were collected as a monophasic material based on the powder XRD. Yield:  22 mg (54% based on Ni). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C10H26N4O20P4Ni3:  C, 14.72 (14.60); H, 3.13 (3.19); N, 6.80 (6.81). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3423(m, br), 3148(m), 2994(m), 1654(w, br), 1571(m), 1544(w), 1454(w), 1397(w), 1317(vw), 1289(m), 1225(vw), 1152(vs), 1053(vs), 982(s), 955(m), 926(w), 893(w), 868(w), 850(m), 762(w), 712(m), 684(w), 639(m), 607(vw), 581(s), 547(m), 517(w), 484(m), 442(w).

Preparation of Co(ImhedpH 3 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (3). A mixture of ImhedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0272 g) and CoSO4·7H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.0281 g) in 8 mL of H2O (pH = 2.80) was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 140 °C for 48 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple blocky crystals were collected as a monophasic material based on the powder XRD. Yield:  19 mg (30% based on Co). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C10H22N4O16P4Co:  C, 18.63 (18.85); H, 3.40 (3.48); N, 8.68 (8.79). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3584(s), 3333(s), 3225−2743(m, br), 1855(w), 1645(m), 1579(m), 1545(m), 1459(w), 1445(m), 1416(w), 1381(w), 1353(w), 1323(w), 1289(m), 1236(m), 1177(s), 1153(vs), 1111(s), 1074(vs), 1047(m), 1017(m), 962(s), 922(s), 898(s), 858(vw), 834(m), 781(vw), 756(m), 715(m), 677(w), 633(m), 594(m), 557(m), 529(m), 481(s), 411(vw).

Preparation of Ni(ImhedpH 3 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (4). A mixture of ImhedpH4 (0.10 mmol, 0.0272 g) and NiSO4·6H2O (0.10 mmol, 0.0263 g) in 8 mL of H2O (pH = 2.72) was kept in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 140 °C for 48 h. After slow cooling to room temperature, light green blocky crystals were collected as a monophasic material based on the powder XRD. Yield:  20 mg (31% based on Ni). Anal. Found (Calcd) for C10H22N4O16P4Ni:  C, 18.74 (18.86); H, 3.59 (3.48); N, 8.66 (8.80)%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3584(s), 3333(s), 3231−2739(m, br), 1854(w), 1648(m), 1578(m), 1544(m), 1458(w), 1444(w), 1417(w), 1381(w), 1353(w), 1322(w), 1290(m), 1233(m), 1176(s), 1154(vs), 1112(s), 1075(vs), 1047(w), 1017(m), 962(s), 922(m), 897(m), 858(w), 836(m), 756(m), 716(m), 678(w), 633(m), 595(m), 560(m), 529(m), 482(s), 412(w).

Results and Discussion

Syntheses. Compounds 1−4 were prepared through hydrothermal reactions of ImhedpH4 and the corresponding metal acetates or sulfates at 160 or 140 °C for 2 days. It was found that the reaction temperature and pH value of the reaction mixture, M/ligand molar ratio, and the metal source play key roles in the formation of the final products. Both 1 and 2 can be prepared as pure phases at 160 °C, pH of 4.5−5.0, and with the M(CH3CO2)2/ligand molar ratio of (0.8−1):1. When the temperature is lowered to 140 °C or the pH value is beyond the range of 4.5−5.0, only flocculelike materials are obtained. Pure phases of compounds 3 and 4 can be obtained at 140 °C when the pH falls in the range of 2.5−3.0 and the MSO4/ligand molar ratio is (0.5−1):1. If we use MSO4 as the starting material in preparing 1 and 2 or M(CH3CO2)2 in preparing 3 and 4, large amounts of the unrecognized flocculelike materials would be obtained. Attempts to synthesize compounds 1 and 2 by using 3 and 4, respectively, as the starting materials were not successful.

cln_elements.content:
Magnetic Properties of Co 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (1). The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of compound 1 were investigated in the temperature range of 1.8−300 K. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Co3 unit (8.78 μB) is much higher than the expected spin-only value for S = 3/2 (6.71 μB), attributed to the orbital contribution of Co(II) ion. The susceptibility data between 90 and 300 K follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ = −12.3 K. Upon cooling from room temperature, χM T decreases continuously until it reaches a minimum of 6.78 cm3·K·mol-1 at 10 K. Below 10 K, χM T increases abruptly to a maximum of 14.82 cm3·K·mol-1 at 3 K and then decreases again to 9.46 cm3·K·mol-1 at 1.8 K (Figure ). This is characteristic for a ferrimagnetic behavior with dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. Besides, the zero-field-cooled magnetism (ZFCM) and field-cooled magnetism (FCM, H dc = 50 Oe) measurements of the dc magnetic susceptibility deviate from each other at ca. 2.6 K, suggesting the onset of a long-range ferromagnetic phase transition below this temperature (Figure , inset).

Magnetic Properties of Ni 3 (ImhedpH) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·2H 2 O (2). The magnetic behavior of compound 2 is analogous to that of compound 1. The room-temperature effective magnetic moment per Ni3 unit (5.60 μB) is close to the expected value (5.38 μB) for spin S = 1 with g = 2.2. Upon cooling from room temperature, the χM T value decreases from 3.92 to 3.17 cm3·K·mol-1 at ca. 14 K, below which it increases rapidly to a maximum of 15.78 cm3·K·mol-1 at 5 K and then decreases again to 7.40 cm3·K·mol-1 at 1.8 K (Figure ). This is typical for ferrimagnetic behavior. The FCM (H dc = 50 Oe) and ZFCM curves diverge at ca. 5.0 K (Figure , inset), suggesting that a long-range magnetic ordering occurs below T c = 5.0 K. The isothermal magnetization M(H) at 1.8 K reveals that the magnetization at 70 kOe (0.86 Nβ) is far below the saturation value of 2.2 Nβ expected for an S = 1 system (g = 2.2), indicating the occurrence of canted antiferromagnetism. The magnetic hysteresis loop is observed at 1.8 K with the coercive field (H c) and the remnant magnetization (M R) being 22.5 Oe and 0.098 Nβ, respectively (Figure ). The canting angle is estimated as 2.6°.
